Description: Scarab carved from light brownish beige steatite; back well defined with detailed clypeus, and prothorax, elytra and triangle at junction with prothorax marked by one or more incised lines; at side, well-shaped legs with undercut triangle and projecting shelf underneath running round beetle; underside incised with Hapy figure, topped with marsh plants, and raised cobra to front; incised details within motif, encircled by incised line; pierced longitudinally, with remains of corroded metal (bronze) inside pierced hole.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This scarab is published as coming from Naukratis (Budge 1893, no. 252). A second scarab from Naukratis displays a figure of a kneeling Hapy, but associated with a Hes vase, not a raised cobra: BM 1888,0601.66. This scarab can be compared to examples found on Punic sites such as Carthage, and belong to Gorton's type XVA (Gorton 1996, 43-8), a Phoenician type of the 7th-6th centuries. Budge, E.A.W. 1893, Catalogue of the Egyptian collection in the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford.
Bibliographic references: Budge 1893b / Catalogue of the Egyptian collection in the Fitzwilliam Museum (no. 252)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OA.04) (phase 3)
